title: Boots proves too bitter a pill to swallow
text:
One scoop to start: Short seller Jim Chanos is betting against “legacy” data centres that face growing competition from the trio of tech giants that have been their biggest customers, he told the Financial Times in an interview.

In today's newsletter:

  • Walgreens calls off its Boots sale

  • European Spacs' target troubles

  • EY gets fined for cheating

Boots proves too bitter a pill to swallow

After taking Alliance Boots private at the apex of the buyout bubble in 2007, KKR ultimately salvaged the deal by selling the pharmacy to US competitor Walgreens.

While that deal survived the 2008 crisis, Walgreens' latest attempt to sell the Boots business is an early casualty of the current market turmoil.

On Tuesday, Walgreens announced it was ending its sale process of Boots due to “unexpected” and “dramatic” changes in financial markets amid the outbreak of war in Ukraine and rising interest rates.

Takeover bids were underwhelming and risked failing to win sturdy financing, it said.

A decade ago, Walgreens' takeover of its UK rival nearly tripled its share price over a three-year stretch as investors warmed up to promised synergies and the prospect of billionaire dealmaker Stefano Pessina running the show.

But optimism has long since faded. The shares are down by half since the end of 2014, when Walgreens completed the buyout.

Pessina stepped down as chief executive to become executive chair two years ago, as retailers saw business plunge amid coronavirus lockdowns. His successor Roz Brewer, the former Starbucks operating chief, is now tasked with unwinding the takeover entirely.

The Boots sale process, run by Goldman Sachs, has been difficult for several months.

CVC, whose would-be bid was being overseen by Dominic Murphy — the man behind KKR's original 2007 buyout — took itself out of the running early on.

Bain, which was planning to bid with CVC, also passed on the opportunity, concerned that the deal might not generate good returns.

Mohsin and Zuber Issa, the billionaire brothers behind petrol station company EG Group and UK supermarket Asda, were also interested in Boots but never submitted a binding bid.

That left a joint bid from Apollo Global Management and Mukesh Ambani's Reliance Industries, which was still being pursued into the weekend, sources told DD.

But Walgreens pulled the plug, underwhelmed by what was offered by Apollo — not typically one to overpay for assets, especially with little competition.

Goldman Sachs has already had a tough time with UK retail deals after struggling to distribute the debt backing Clayton, Dubilier & Rice's takeover of Wm Morrison.

Walgreens will remain on UK high streets for now. But has it missed its exit opportunity ahead of grim economic times on the horizon?

There was a time just before the pandemic when KKR was considering a $70bn buyout of all of Walgreens, drawing caution from Blackstone chief Stephen Schwarzman, who questioned whether the industry could pull off such a big deal.

Now, as financing markets plumb lows reminiscent of the crisis era, the question is whether much of anything will get done this summer.

Europe's mad dash for Spac deals

European dealmakers may have caught Spac fever later than their Wall Street counterparts, but the symptoms have proven just as painful.

DD readers are by now well-acquainted with characters such as Jean Pierre Mustier, the former UniCredit boss, and LVMH founder Bernard Arnault.

The two Frenchmen teamed up last year with former Bank of America banker Diego De Giorgi and Tikehau Capital to launch Pegasus Europe, the continent's largest special purpose acquisition company, with their sights set on Europe's red-hot financial services sector.

But more than a year after it raised €484mn in a listing in Amsterdam, the go-to destination for European Spacs at the time, Pegasus is among many of the continent's blank-cheque companies that have failed to find a merger target, the FT's Owen Walker and Sarah White report.

The biggest obstacles to getting a deal done? Lofty fintech valuations that Mustier and De Giorgi were unwilling to meet, which made it difficult to agree on price.

“The Pegasus Europe guys made two mistakes,” said one European investment banker involved in Spacs. “They raised too much money and they defined the scope [of the target] too narrowly.”

Time is ticking for Pegasus and the 57 other European blank-cheque companies that have yet to find a target.

Like most Spacs, Pegasus has two years from the date of its listing to nail down a merger. That gives it until next May, though it can seek shareholder approval for a six-month extension.

Not all European Spacs are stuck in purgatory. In May, Tikehau and Arnault's separate vehicle Pegasus Entrepreneurs struck a deal to list Master Chef and Black Mirror producer Banijay.

And unlike most investors, Spac sponsors have been feeling optimistic about the recent market turmoil. As soaring inflation dries up the record amount of investment poured into fintechs in 2021, Pegasus could finally find a deal at a lower valuation.  

A Big Four firm's big ‘no-no'

Here's a quick test for DD readers.

Cheating is (a) bad, (b) very bad, or (c) even worse when you're in the business of holding other companies accountable.

Jokes aside, EY has been fined a record $100mn by the Securities and Exchange Commission to resolve claims that dozens of its employees cheated on the ethics portion of the Certified Public Accountants exam.

The SEC have very kindly summed up how bad this looks for EY: “It's simply outrageous that the very professionals responsible for catching cheating by clients cheated on ethics exams of all things,” said Gurbir Grewal, director of the SEC's enforcement division.

Believe it or not, this isn't the first time employees at one of the Big Four have been caught cheating. KPMG paid a $50mn penalty in 2019 for exam cheating and illegal tip-offs.

According to the SEC, EY has been fined twice that sum partly because it misled regulators when they made inquiries after the KPMG scandal. EY said nothing to the SEC or the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board, even while launching an internal investigation that confirmed instances of cheating.

This is obviously terrible public relations for EY, which as DD readers know is weighing plans to split its audit and advisory practices globally.

EY said that its response to “this unacceptable past behaviour has been thorough, extensive, and effective”, adding that it would take steps to “strengthen” commitments to “compliance, ethics, and integrity”. 

Hopefully none of those steps are a multiple-choice exam.

Job moves

  • Goldman Sachs' co-chair of global M&A Michael Carr is retiring after 25 years at the Wall Street investment bank, according to a memo seen by DD. He will stay on as an advisory director following his retirement.

  • Jupiter Fund Management chief executive Andrew Formica is retiring after only three years in the role, with the asset manager having underperformed its rivals. He will be replaced by its chief investment officer, Matthew Beesley, who joined from rival Artemis earlier this year. More here from Lex.

  • Akash Ambani has been named chair of his father Mukesh Ambani's Reliance Jio, marking the beginning of a succession plan within one of Asia's wealthiest families.

  • Walt Disney's board has voted unanimously to extend Bob Chapek's contract as chief executive for three years.

  • McDonald's has named Ian Borden as its chief financial officer, effective in September. He is replacing Kevin Ozan, who will assume the role of senior executive vice-president.

  • Toshiba board member Mariko Watahiki resigned on Tuesday shortly after shareholders approved the appointments of hedge fund members to the board, including Eijiro Imai, a managing director at Farallon Capital Japan, and Nabeel Bhanji, a senior portfolio manager at Elliott Management.

Smart reads

To binge, or not to binge Netflix's binge-watching model revolutionised Hollywood. But its signature strategy is being thrown into disarray by an influx of streaming rivals embracing the traditional, and more profitable, release model, The Wall Street Journal writes.

Bankruptcy court's wild west French manufacturer Saint-Gobain saved billions in potential liabilities for asbestos-related cancers by enlisting law firm Jones Day and its signature “Texas two-step” bankruptcy method. Now, one of its own attorneys has blown the whistle on the secretive legal process, Reuters reports.

BuzzFeed's Spac screw-up The digital media group's slumping stock price is only the tip of the iceberg. It now faces a legal reckoning from some employees who were unable to trade their shares following its blank-cheque debut, New York Magazine writes.
